summary: This document is an internal report from the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) detailing plans to offer deferred prosecution agreements to two correctional officers, Tova Noel and Michael Thomas. The officers were charged with falsifying records related to inmate counts and rounds on the night Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the Manhattan Correctional Center (MCC). The agreements require their cooperation with an OIG investigation, admissions of guilt, community service, and pretrial supervision.

events.title: Falsification of Prison Records Begins

keyFacts: Two correctional officers, Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, were charged with falsifying institutional count and round forms on the night Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the MCC.
The officers admitted to a supervisor that they failed to conduct required counts and rounds after discovering Epstein's body, though the falsification occurred prior to the discovery.
The USAO-SDNY determined deferred prosecution agreements were consistent with justice, citing the officers' mitigating personal circumstances and Department practice in similar cases.

The deferred prosecution agreements require the officers to admit guilt, cooperate with the Office of Inspector General's investigation, complete 100 hours of community service, and be under pretrial supervision for six months.
The agreement does not preclude administrative action or termination by the Bureau of Prisons, and the outcome was supported by the DOJ OIG, FBI, and approved by Pretrial Services.
